Come into this game knowing there's only like 5 fighters (I think. There may be more, I haven't even beat everyone yet). Don't expect there to be more. There are flaws of course. For starters, one of the first things I noticed is the fact that you don't really have a "stance". That said, these flaws are less "the developer doesn't care" and more "these are the limitations with our current VR tech/dev budget/man hours", and they are absolutely within reason and do not kill the experience.

Don't go into this game thinking it's going to be a fun punching thing (like Punch-Out!!). Don't go in and expect this game to deliver the perfect fighting experience, THE definitive fighting experience for years to come (though it probably actually fits that description as of now). tl;dr, Worth it. I'm excited to see where this game goes in it's early access state, but would still be happy if the dev came out tomorrow like "Ok, it's done!" and released it as is.

32740578.review:
I've had about 5 years of combat sport experience. Full disclosure, it was MMA so that experience is more aligned with Muay Thai / American Kickboxing styles than classic boxing. While there are certainly differences between the styles, the 'feeling' of hitting someone in the face and emotions range felt during a match are probably pretty close. That being said I couldn't be happier to have something like this available. 

VR really opened the door to this level of immersion for sure, but all credit should go to the developer behind this. It's truly remarkable what he's accomplished. Getting the pacing and feeling of some of the nuances of the sport and actual act of fighting someone without actually having boxed himself is worth the price of admission alone. 

For perspective, I tried Knockout League and had to shut it off after the first fight for one simple reason; It committed the same sin virtually every other VR or motion controlled fighting game has before it. [b]It did'nt take the user seriously[/b], watered down physics that have more to do with a rhythm game or timing game on guardrails than a fight. 

Is ToTF perfect, the only thing missing is the concussion and black eyes? Of course not, but IMO it's leaps beyond anything else mechanically and "experience" wise. I know that is a word that gets thrown around a lot, but it's well earned for this title. For  example, even the 1st opponent takes me back to exactly what it was like to lightly spar with a training partner. Not too hard, not too slow, focusing on technique and movement. 

Pairing the current experience with a super responsive Dev, frequent updates that are almost always a love letter to the (active) community on the forums and you have a winner worth 3x the asking price. Personally, I can't wait to see where this game goes as we are treated to frequent and meaningful updates.

[b]Additional context, or to address some potential purchaser preconceptions:[/b]

If you are looking into this as something to TEACH you to fight, I'll say this. It's not an instructional. HOWEVER. If you use some common sense, watch some instructional videos or books on the subject, you can ABSOLUTELY drill and refine technique and precision. This is valuable in a way that goes beyond pad or bag work as you can gauge actual distance and get used to 'picking apart' a defense. With the addition of the round system, it can also teach you good pacing. Just like real life, conserving your energy is a huge part of fight strategy. 

When I was actively training, I was unfortunate enough to be one of those people that felt bad for hitting someone too hard that I trained with. It's more common than you think, and with a game like this it allows you to get the 'feel' of things like (distance) timing and even evasion down without taking or doing any actual damage - except maybe to furniture or TVs if you don't strap in. 

The big exceptions to what isn't going to build good real world habits are some intermediate level footwork stuff like cut and gate steps based on AI tracking and/or play area limitations. You can still make these movements of course, but you don't get the same angles you would IRL if you really make someone miss. The only other thing this game doesn't do is actually hit you back.

For better explanation of pros/cons, read below.

Pros:
- Fun
- Good workout
- Pretty decent AI so far (it says I only have 10 minutes on record, but there's no way - I did four training sessions and fought the first boxer twice, going 1-1).
- Does not teach great punching skills, but is great for dodging and timing. Movement depends on your available space.
- Innovative use of Vive controller mechanics by changing the grip you use. I was only skeptic for the first five seconds, and then I was sold.
- Great for an inde game with probably a low budget.
- At full price USD I only paid $10. I can already tell I'm going to be revisiting this often enough to make the dollars/hour spent very cheap.
- Actually decent cardio for a game. There's a reason rounds are 3:00 in boxing.

Cons:
- Training is school of hard knox.
- Actual punching skills developed is probably not high.
- AI ignores punches if it is in the process of swinging.
- AI got right in my face. Not sure if that was intentional, or just the software not reading my position correctly, but given the very strategic nature of the dodge-punch-dodge mechanics, this made even the starting opponent a pain.
- Game placed opponent between myself and my PC, which means I was constantly tripping over the headset cord.

I used to do American boxing for sport, been in a few matches, got knocked out once with a concussion (it was an unofficial match with gloves and mouth guards, but no headgear - wear your headgear, kids, leave the "no headgear" to the professionals who can afford it). In the last year or so I've switched into other forms of boxing and fighting, but I've let my cardio slide due to injuries and day job volume.

This game punished me for it, and I like it. I can still hit a bag for a few rounds, but hitting the empty air is much more tiring. I wouldn't consider it a "simulator," most VR games that attempt to give you a feel for something aren't quite advanced enough, but give it time, I'm sure. The feeling of connecting with a good punch just isn't there. A well-swung roundhouse when your opponent is wide open gets completely ignored if the game was expecting you to block or dodge his slow straight right. The AI registers it was hit by wincing, but continues through with it's action. I suppose otherwise, you could just roll your fists around like patty cake and win every match.

That being said, it's a lot of fun and will teach you some boxing fundamentals, I just wish there was more of a tutorial. If you dodge too early, your opponent will change direction and still hit you. Dodge too late, and obviously you still get hit. This is where it shines in the realm of "actual boxing." It took me a few practice sessions to understand what it was doing.

EDIT: Forgot to mention the AI getting in my face - again, this is a game, not a simulation, but in that type of situation, you would go for body shots or lock up and look for an opportunity to deliver quick jabs/hooks until my opponent backed off. AI does *not* care, and will throw almost impossible punches that should slip by you instead of nailing you in the face. If you're almost forehead-to-forehead with someone, and they throw a full-shoulder straight right, a slight dodge of the head and it will blow past your ear, over your shoulder, and leave them exposed for a counter-hook. Half-step back, bam. Not here. Admitting this is not a simulation, the game needs AI that recognizes appropriate distance based on height and head position, and react accordingly. I'm 6'0", dev, if you read this and that helps. I did not cheat at the weigh-in (which records your height, apparently) by lowering or raising myself.

Also as I mentioned above as a con, the game decided my opponent would be in the direction of my PC. That meant the cord fell right next to my legs, which made dodging very difficult. I appreciate the fact that when I did successfully side-step, the AI followed.

All-in-all, I think the game successfully sets out to do what it intends to do - be a fun boxing game, not a sim, not a training tool. While those features would be very cool, for $10, I can't complain at all. I've spent a lot more than that on lessons, books, and gym time, and while this doesn't offer the same benefit - because it's a game and not a simulation - it has definite merit, and is a great workout.

As a person who did boxing as a hobby in college, I am very happy with this game and defintiely recommend it (especially because it is not a wave shooter like the rest of the VR games out there). I can block, bob and weave, counter punch when the computer throws punches (uppercuts, cross, hooks), so it's a great alternative to shadowboxing because you can practice defense at the same time. The blocking stamina mechanic is a good compromise so people dont cheese the system. 

However, since it is an early access game it is low on content (only one practice opponent and one real opponent), but I am sure the developer will add more soon since he has been very receptive to feedback and quick with his updates since his demo. The core mechanics are very solid and it is definitely worth the current price.
